HOME.1: The Pályaalkalmassági Vizsgálat (PÁV) is a mandatory psychological and skills assessment for professional drivers in Hungary. In addition to computer-based tests that evaluate reaction speed and attention, the process also includes a personal interview with a psychologist to assess personality traits and driving attitude.
HOME.2: This simulator helps you practice the computer-based portion of the exam. To begin, please select a test from the navigation menu above.

INSTRUCTIONS.DESCRIPTION: The monotony test presents repeated visual patterns. Your task is to quickly decide if the bottom pattern matches the category of correct patterns shown above. The test measures sustained attention under monotonous conditions.
INSTRUCTIONS.DESCRIPTION2: The official test may use different visual patterns; this simulator captures the general idea only. There is no public, official documentation on the exact scoring method and the duration of the test, but it takes between 5–10 minutes.

STEPS.GOAL: Goal: If the bottom pattern is in the correct set, press Yes; otherwise press No.
STEPS.DURATION: Duration: The test runs for 7 minutes unless you stop it.
STEPS.SCORING: Scoring: Each response counts toward your total; correct answers increase your score.
STEPS.TIPS: Tip: Focus on the structural rules of the correct set rather than memorizing individual shapes.

INSTRUCTIONS.DESCRIPTION: The Vienna Determination Test (DT) is a cognitive assessment tool from the Vienna Test System commonly used in driving aptitude evaluations. It tests reaction speed, attention, and stress tolerance through multiple-choice reactions to different stimuli.

STEPS.SPEED: Select a speed (Slow, Medium, or Fast) and click "Start".
STEPS.COLORS: When a colored circle appears in the top rows, press the corresponding color key.
STEPS.PEDALS: When one of the bottom rectangles (left or right) turns white, press the corresponding key.
STEPS.SOUNDS: When you hear a sound, press the key that matches the tone (deep or high).
STEPS.TIMING: You must respond to each signal before the next one appears.
